title: New elite coaches group urges easing of handball law
body_text:
Expect to see fewer penalties awarded for handball in the Champions League next season.

UEFA's new Football Board, a gathering of elite coaches and ex-players tasked to discuss the laws of the game, agreed on new guidance for referees in its competitions.
"The Board recommends that UEFA should clarify that no handball offence should be called on a player if the ball is previously deflected from his own body and, in particular, when the ball does not go towards the goal," the European governing body said in a statement on Tuesday.
The coaches also agreed that "not every handball should automatically lead to a caution after every shot at goal," UEFA said, and that referees should show yellow cards to players who fake being injured or pretend to have been fouled.
There have been several controversial handball decisions in this year's competition, including against Leipzig's Benjamin Henrichs away to Manchester City. A penalty was given, converted by Erling Haaland it proved the first goal of a 7-0 win.
UEFA can give specific guidelines to referees in its own competitions but cannot change the fundamental Laws of the Game, a process managed by FIFA.
The inaugural Football Board - which includes Carlo Ancelotti, Jose Mourinho and Zinedine Zidane - met on Monday in Nyon, three weeks after UEFA president Aleksander Ceferin promised it would be created and review handball offences he said were increasingly confusing to players and fans.
The new grouping is led by Zvonimir Boban, the former Croatia and AC Milan great who previously worked at FIFA and is now a key adviser to Ceferin.
"The handball rule, for example, will always be disputed but we can make it more consistent and aligned with the game's true nature," Boban said.
Monday's meeting also included national-team coaches Gareth Southgate, Ronald Koeman and Roberto Martinez, plus Philipp Lahm, the former Germany captain.
Australian Associated Press
